newsitem.title: UK: Glaxo plays down inhaler findings.
newsitem.headline: Glaxo plays down inhaler findings.

text.p: Glaxo Wellcome Plc on Wednesday played down the significance of research findings that suggested an increased glaucoma risk from elderly asthma suffers taking inhaled steroids over an extended period.

A Glaxo spokesman said the findings, published in the Journal of the American Medical Association, appeared to have done no more than highlight a long-established link between a slightly increased risk of glaucoma and steriod inhalation.
"We are talking about a relatively small number of cases despite widespread use for some 20 years," the spokesman said.

"As far as we are concerned the study indicates a small increase in the risk of taking high doses over a long period, and it is likely that such patients have had very severe symptoms and their cases have therefore been complicated by taking other treatments."

Earlier market talk about the findings, along with an earnings reduction by Goldman Sachs, helped unsettle Glaxo shares ahead of the company's annual results on Thursday. The company is a major supplier of inhaled steroids.

Glaxo shares reached a record 10.63 stg in early trading before retreating to be down 26-1/2p at 10.29-1/2 by 1220 GMT. With other major drug stocks Zeneca Group Plc and SmithKline Beecham Plc also under pressure, dealers said there were signs of profit-taking across the sector.
